message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Debate "character" for 德">
The author is considering "character" for 德. Those who voted against it — what is your single strongest objection to "character"? Those who voted for it — what is its single strongest advantage?

Also: we now know 性 does NOT appear as a standalone technical term in the collection, so the "nature" collision concern is off the table.

Brief responses — one strongest point each.
</teammate-message>

input.content: **Strongest objection to "character":** It is ambiguous in exactly the wrong way. When the reader encounters "all things have their character," the most natural English reading is personality or temperament -- a descriptive property that a thing *happens to have*. But the author's 德 is constitutive -- what *makes* a thing what it is. "Character" does not carry that constitutive force without a modifier. "Defining character" or "constitutive nature" both fix this; bare "character" does not.

routing.content: **Strongest objection to "character":** It is ambiguous in exactly the wrong way. When the reader encounters "all things have their character," the most natural English reading is personality or temperament -- a descriptive property that a thing *happens to have*. But the author's 德 is constitutive -- what *makes* a thing what it is. "Character" does not carry that constitutive force without a modifier. "Defining character" or "constitutive nature" both fix this; bare "character" does not.

content.text: Bare "character" reads as descriptive (what a thing happens to be like) rather than constitutive (what makes a thing what it is). Needs a modifier. Standing by.
